questions.text: A 25yr old woman came to OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale, and investigations show a HB of 5mg/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count ? (take normal Hb as 15mg/dl) (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Corrected reticulocyte count (CRC)= reticulocyte % X (actual Hb/normal Hb)

 

CRC= 9 X 5/15 = 3%

 

CRC can also be calculated using hematocrit

 

CRC= Reticulocyte % X (Actual PCV/ normal PCV )

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) adjusts the observed reticulocyte percentage to reflect the degree of anemia by using the patient's actual hemoglobin compared to a normal hemoglobin level.

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is crucial for assessing bone marrow response in anemic patients, providing insight into whether the bone marrow is responding appropriately to the anemia. This is particularly important in managing patients with iron deficiency anemia to monitor recovery or response to therapy.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. For women under the age of 35, it is recommended to wait and try for one year before starting any investigations. Since the woman in this scenario is only 23 years old and has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, the best approach is to reassure her and advise her to continue trying. Investigations are not indicated at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semen analysis for husband: Although semen analysis is an essential part of infertility workup, it is typically not indicated until the couple has been trying to conceive for at least one year if the woman is under 35 years old.

 

Option C. Hysterolaparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure used to evaluate the female reproductive tract, typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations suggest abnormalities or for women who have been trying to conceive for a longer period.

 

Option D. Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This procedure is used to examine the inside of the uterus and is generally indicated for investigating suspected uterine abnormalities or after a longer period of unsuccessful conception attempts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women under 35 years old, it is recommended to try to conceive for one year before starting infertility investigations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

Enterococci are gram-positive bacteria, and the first-line treatment for enterococcal infections is typically ampicillin. However, in patients with penicillin allergies, vancomycin is the preferred alternative. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, leading to bacterial cell death.

 

 

  • Linezolid               
  • Tigecycline (Complicated Skin/Intra-abdominal Infections)
  • Daptomycin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria particularly in community-acquired pneumonia in ICU patients with a penicillin allergy, Aztreonam is the best choice.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. While effective against some gram-positive bacteria, it is not the preferred choice for enterococcal infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergies due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: This is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. It would not be safe to use in a patient with a penicillin allergy due to the risk of a severe allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with various structural, behavioral, and developmental anomalies due to prenatal alcohol exposure. One of the key features of FAS is microcephaly, not macrocephaly. High levels of alcohol ingestion during pregnancy can severely impact embryonic and fetal development.

 

The presence of at least one of the following characteristics is indicative of fetal alcohol syndrome:

 

  • Growth restriction: Can occur before and/or after birth.
  • Facial anomalies: These include small palpebral fissures, indistinct or absent philtrum, epicanthic folds, flattened nasal bridge, short length of nose, thin upper lip, low-set and unparallel ears, and retarded midfacial development.
  • CNS dysfunction: Includes microcephaly, mental retardation, and abnormal neurobehavioral development such as attention deficit with hyperactivity.

 

Other features that may be seen in FAS include:

 

  • Incomplete holoprosencephaly: A condition where the forebrain does not completely divide into two hemispheres.
  • Agenesis of the corpus callosum and cerebellar vermis: Developmental anomalies where these brain structures are partially or completely absent.
  • Cardiac anomalies: Such as ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Macrocephaly is not seen in fetal alcohol syndrome; instead, microcephaly is characteristic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a characteristic finding in fetal alcohol syndrome due to developmental anomalies.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: This is commonly seen in fetal alcohol syndrome and is one of the diagnostic features.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: Incomplete holoprosencephaly can be seen in fetal alcohol syndrome as a result of severe midline developmental anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

Ref: Page no 397, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient on antidepressants presented to you with hypotension. An ECG was done, which showed wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IV NaHCO3

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, which includes hypotension, wide QRS complexes, and right axis deviation on the ECG. TCAs can block sodium channels in the heart, leading to QRS widening and the potential for serious arrhythmias. They also have anticholinergic effects, which can contribute to the clinical picture.

 

The first-line treatment for TCA overdose, especially in the presence of cardiac toxicity such as wide QRS complexes, is intravenous sodium bicarbonate (IV NaHCO3). Sodium bicarbonate works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to overcome the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs. It also increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which can help stabilize cardiac cell membranes and improve conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antiarrhythmics: While antiarrhythmics might be considered in other cases of cardiac arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for TCA overdose. In fact, some antiarrhythmic drugs can worsen the condition by further blocking sodium channels or prolonging the QT interval.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure and certain types of arrhythmias. However, it is not indicated for the treatment of TCA toxicity and can potentially exacerbate hypotension and cardiac conduction abnormalities.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant that can also be used for certain types of arrhythmias. However, it is not effective in treating the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs and is not recommended for managing TCA overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for tricyclic antidepressant overdose, especially when presenting with wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation, is intravenous sodium bicarbonate (IV NaHCO3).

choices.text: Induce labor by artificial rupture of membranes
Sedate the patient and give Phenergan to reduce labor pains
Monitor the patient and wait for stronger uterine contractions

questions.text: A 38-week pregnant woman in her first pregnancy arrives at the labor room with mild labor pains and contractions. On examination, her cervix is 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. Her heart rate is 86/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate next step? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Monitor the patient and wait for stronger uterine contractions

 

In a first-time mother (primigravida), labor progression can be slow. Given that the patient is at term and her vital signs are stable, the best course of action is to observe and wait for labor to progress naturally. Regular monitoring of the patient's vitals and labor progress is essential. Inducing or augmenting labor at this stage is not necessary unless there are signs of complications or inadequate labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Induce labor by artificial rupture of membranes - This intervention is not necessary at this stage as labor can progress naturally.

 

Option B. Administer oxytocin to augment labor - Augmentation is not required unless labor is not progressing adequately.

 

Option C. Sedate the patient and give Phenergan to reduce labor pains - Sedation is not indicated for managing early labor pains and could hinder labor progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a primigravida at term with mild labor contractions and stable vitals, it is appropriate to monitor and wait for labor to progress naturally

questions.text: Identify the given ECG? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Torsade’s de pointes

 

Torsade’s de pointes is characterized by a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with varying QRS complex amplitudes and a twisting around the baseline.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Characterized by a chaotic and irregular waveform without identifiable QRS complexes.
 

Option C. Atrial flutter: Shows a sawtooth pattern of atrial activity.
 

Option D. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: Shows uniform QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Torsade’s de pointes are a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic twisting pattern.

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 6 to 7 months

 

Crown rump length + length of lower limb = crown heel length

 

According to the Rule of Haase

 

  • Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (when the crown-heel length is 25 cm or less/ first 5 months).
  • Age in months = crown-heel length divided by 5 (when the crown-heel length is more than 25 cm/ last 5 months).

 

Here, crown heel length = Crown rump + lower limb length = 31 cm.

 

Hence, gestational age = 31 / 5 = 6-7 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rule of Haase can be used to estimate gestational age from fetal measurements. For a crown-heel length greater than 25 cm, the gestational age is calculated by dividing the crown-heel length by 5.

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify auto antibodies? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect immunofluorescence

 

  • Indirect immunofluorescence is a technique commonly used for the detection of autoantibodies. It involves applying the patient's serum to a substrate that expresses the antigen(s) of interest. If autoantibodies are present, they bind to these antigens. Then another anti-human antibody is added to amplify the response generated. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Immunofluorescence: Used for tissue-bound antibodies where the patient's tissues are stained directly to detect deposits of immunoglobulins or complement.

 

Option B. ELISA: Mainly used for quantifying serum levels of specific antibodies against predefined antigens.

 

Option D. FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization): Used for identifying chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations rather than detecting antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect immunofluorescence allows for the detection of circulating autoantibodies in patient serum by using antigen-expressing substrates, making it a critical tool for diagnosing various autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Where are the Ito cells in the liver located? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Space of disse

 

In the Disse space are Ito cells/Hepatic stellate cells. Their origins are mesenchymal.

 

Between the liver sinusoid and the hepatocytes is a region known as the space of Disse, sometimes known as the perisinusoidal space.

 

Significance of Ito cells:

 

Most of the time, ito cells (also known as stellate cells) are dormant. They are a substantial source of growth factors essential for liver homeostasis and regeneration and store the fat-soluble vitamin A in their lipid droplets.

 

Ito cells become active when there is liver damage. They release intralobular matrix components such collagen type III (reticular) fibres and replace injured hepatocytes with collagenous scar tissue. This leads to hepatic fibrosis.

 

Note: A narrow space which separates limiting plate (a sleeve of modified hepatocytes) from the connective tissue of the portal area is known as space of moll.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Space of Moll:

 

  • The Space of Moll is located in the eyelid and is not related to the liver. Specifically, it refers to a part of the eyelid's lymphatic drainage system.
  • It has no relevance to the location of Ito cells.

 

Option C. Sinusoids:

 

  • Sinusoids are the capillary-like vessels in the liver where the exchange of substances occurs between the blood and hepatocytes.
  • While Ito cells are closely related to sinusoids and are found in the perisinusoidal space, they are not located within the sinusoids themselves.

 

Option D. Bile Canaliculi:

 

  • Bile canaliculi are small ducts between hepatocytes that collect bile produced by the hepatocytes.
  • Ito cells are not located in the bile canaliculi. Instead, these canaliculi are lined by hepatocytes that actively secrete bile into them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Space of Disse (perisinusoidal space) is a small space between the sinusoidal endothelial cells and the hepatocytes. Ito cells are located in this space. When there is liver injury, these cells can become activated, transform into myofibroblast-like cells, and contribute to the production of collagen and extracellular matrix, leading to liver fibrosis.

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. O positive

 

The agglutination test is a blood test used to determine an individual's blood type. In the case of O positive blood, the test involves mixing a sample of the person's blood with two different types of antibodies: anti-A and anti-B.

 

The person's blood cells do not agglutinate in the presence of either antibody, it indicates that the person's blood type is O positive. This means that the person's blood cells do not contain either the A or B antigen, but do contain the Rh factor antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in the B panel, indicating the absence of B antigens.

 

Option B. A positive: Incorrect as there is no agglutination in the A panel, indicating the absence of A antigens.

 

Option D. AB positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in both A and B panels, which would be required for AB blood type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of agglutination with anti-A and anti-B antibodies and the presence of agglutination with anti-Rh antibodies confirms the blood group as O positive. This means the individual's red blood cells lack A and B antigens but contain the Rh factor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. On physical examination, a visible mass is noted inside the right nasal cavity. The CT scan report is shown below. Given the patient's symptoms and the imaging findings, what is the most likely underlying cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inverted papilloma

 

Inverted papilloma, also known as transitional cell papilloma, Schneiderian papilloma, or Ringertz tumor, is a benign but locally invasive tumor of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. This tumor is characterized by hyperplastic papillomatous tissue growing into the stroma in an endophytic (inward) pattern rather than an exophytic (outward) one. It most commonly arises from the lateral wall of the nasal cavity, specifically near the middle meatus.

 

The primary cause is often linked to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, and it predominantly affects males aged 40-70 years. Clinically, inverted papilloma presents with unilateral symptoms such as nasal obstruction, discharge, and epistaxis (nosebleeds). If the tumor extends into the orbit, it can cause additional symptoms like proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.

 

Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies such as CT or MRI, which help to assess the location and extent of the tumor. A biopsy is essential to confirm the diagnosis. The preferred treatment for inverted papilloma is medial maxillectomy, a surgical procedure designed to remove the tumor and prevent recurrence due to its locally invasive nature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: This malignant tumor can present similarly but is more aggressive and often shows signs of bone erosion on imaging, unlike the localized and benign nature of inverted papilloma.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: This benign but highly vascular tumor typically affects adolescent males and is less common in older adults. It usually arises in the nasopharynx, not the lateral nasal wall.

 

Option D. Sinonasal lymphoma: Lymphomas can cause nasal masses but often present with systemic symptoms and diffuse involvement rather than the well-defined mass and localized presentation typical of inverted papilloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor most commonly found on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity near the middle meatus. It typically presents with unilateral symptoms such as nasal obstruction, discharge, and epistaxis. Diagnosis requires imaging and biopsy, and treatment involves surgical excision through medial maxillectomy to prevent recurrence. Understanding its distinct endophytic growth pattern and the role of HPV in its etiology is crucial for effective management.

choices.text: Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and atony

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

The false statement regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is option A. The standard practice for managing PPH is to start intravenous isotonic crystalloids rather than colloids. Colloids are generally reserved for specific situations and are not the initial choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH. The correct approach involves using crystalloids to replace lost blood volume. The recommendation is not to administer colloids at a volume four times the amount of blood lost.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth: This statement is true. Primary or early postpartum hemorrhage refers to blood loss occurring within the first 24 hours after delivery.

 

Option C. PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery: This statement is true. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery and more than 1000 ml following a cesarean section.

 

Option D. Causes include retained placenta and atony: This statement is true. Common causes of postpartum hemorrhage include uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract) and retained placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of post-partum hemorrhage should involve intravenous isotonic crystalloids, not colloids.

 

Ref: Page 1894, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

questions.text: A pregnant female with known cardiac disease presents in the first trimester with history of warfarin embryopathy. What should be advised now? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

 

Warfarin readily crosses the placenta and is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when exposure occurs between the 6th and 9th weeks of pregnancy. Warfarin embryopathy is characterized by stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia.

 

Management guidelines for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves requiring anticoagulation:

 

  • First trimester: Women on warfarin should be switched to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed to avoid teratogenic effects.
  • Second and third trimesters (13 to 36 weeks): Warfarin can be resumed as it is the most effective anticoagulant in preventing thromboembolic events.
  • Near delivery: Warfarin should be switched back to heparin around delivery to avoid complications. Heparin should be stopped prior to delivery.

 

Mechanical heart valves: Require lifelong anticoagulation, whereas bioprosthetic valves do not require lifelong anticoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin throughout the pregnancy: Continuing warfarin throughout the pregnancy is not advisable due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy and potential fetal hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Give accoumarin: Accoumarin is not a standard recommendation for anticoagulation in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option D. Use LMW heparin: While low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is safer in pregnancy compared to warfarin, the specific recommendation is to switch to heparin in the first trimester and possibly back to warfarin in the second and third trimesters, depending on individual risk assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with mechanical heart valves on warfarin, switch to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed in the first trimester to avoid teratogenic effects, and manage anticoagulation carefully throughout the pregnancy to minimize risks to both mother and fetus.

 

 

Algorithm for management of women with prosthetic heart valves requiring anti-coagulation in pregnancy

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2406

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, and bradycardia. Examination revealed non-pitting edema of the extremities. She has a long-standing history of weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myxedema coma

 

The patient presents with several symptoms indicative of severe hypothyroidism. These include altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, bradycardia, non-pitting edema, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. In hypothyroid patients, a severe, life-threatening condition called myxedema coma can develop. This is characterized by a profound deficiency of thyroid hormones, leading to critical manifestations such as altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and edema.

 

Myxedema coma requires immediate medical intervention. The treatment of choice involves intravenous administration of thyroxine (IV T4) and IV hydrocortisone. IV hydrocortisone is essential because many patients with myxedema coma have subtle adrenal insufficiency, which can become overt with the initiation of thyroid hormone replacement. This combination helps stabilize the patient's condition and addresses both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic shock: While this condition involves hypotension and altered sensorium, it is usually associated with signs of infection, fever, and a source of sepsis, which are not described in this patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: This condition involves heart failure and typically presents with signs of fluid overload, severe breathlessness, and possibly chest pain, none of which are noted in this patient’s history.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: The symptoms of hyperthyroidism include weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, and increased bowel movements, which are opposite to the symptoms exhibited by this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening condition of profound hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as altered sensorium, bradycardia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema. Immediate treatment involves IV thyroxine and IV hydrocortisone to manage both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiency

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

 

  • Stepwise devascularization in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves:
    1. Ligation of the uterine arteries:
      • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated at the lateral border between the upper and lower uterine segments.
    2. Ligation of the ovarian and uterine artery anastomoses:
      • Done just below the ovarian ligament.
      • Sometimes, temporary occlusion of the ovarian vessels may be achieved using rubber sleeved clamps.
    3. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
      • This step reduces blood flow by decreasing the pulse pressure by 85%.
      • Ligation can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is not typically involved in the stepwise devascularization for managing atonic PPH.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: Ligation of the vaginal artery is not part of the typical sequence in managing atonic PPH.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery and vaginal artery are not typically targeted in the stepwise devascularization for atonic PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET May 2021)

 

1. Superior gluteal artery

2. Inferior gluteal artery

3. Superior vesical artery

4. Middle rectal artery

5. Inferior vesical artery

6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

 

The internal iliac artery serves as a major artery supplying the pelvic organs, walls, and gluteal region. It divides into anterior and posterior divisions, each giving rise to specific branches that supply different pelvic structures. The branches of the anterior division typically supply the pelvic viscera and some pelvic walls.

 

 

Branches from the anterior division:

 

2. Inferior gluteal artery : Supplies the buttock and lower limb.

 

3. Superior vesical artery : Supplies the bladder and can contribute to the upper ureter and seminal vesicles.

 

4. Middle rectal artery : Supplies the rectum.

 

5. Inferior vesical artery : Supplies the bladder, prostate, and seminal vesicles in males; replaced by the vaginal artery in females.

 

6. Vaginal artery : Supplies the vagina and base of the bladder in females; it is often considered the female equivalent of the inferior vesical artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PT

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

 

 

Causes of prolonged PT:

 

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

 

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

 

Causes of prolonged APTT:

 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time): APTT evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. It measures the time taken for plasma to clot after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and calcium, but without tissue thromboplastin. APTT is used to assess the intrinsic pathway involving factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII, as well as the common pathway.

 

Option C. TT (Thrombin Time): TT measures the final step of the coagulation process—conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin after the addition of thrombin. It does not evaluate either the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways specifically but rather the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option D. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is a test that assesses platelet function and the initial phase of hemostasis but does not evaluate the coagulation pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade by measuring the time it takes for plasma to clot after the addition of tissue thromboplastin and calcium. It is commonly prolonged in conditions such as vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, and the use of vitamin K antagonists.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic Basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 232

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

The concentration of chloride on the luminal side is more when compared to sodium, glucose, and amino acids.

 

In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes thus decreasing their concentrations markedly along the length of the proximal tubule. Thus, the solution will have a higher concentration of chloride which is around 105 mEg/L.

 

In the second half of the proximal tubule, sodium gets re-absorbed along with chloride. Higher chloride (approx. 140meq/L) concentration favors its own diffusion from the lumen into the renal interstitial fluid.

 

Proximal tubule’s high permeability to water, increases water reabsorption thus helps in maintaining sodium concentration and total osmolarity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Their concentration decreases significantly due to nearly complete reabsorption.

 

Option B. Glucose: Similarly, glucose concentration decreases significantly because of active reabsorption.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: Its concentration also decreases due to active reabsorption facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule does not decrease as significantly as amino acids, glucose, and bicarbonate due to the preferential reabsorption of these other solutes in the early segments of the PCT.

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2nd Palmar interossei

 

The dorsal digital extension of the middle finger is the structure indicated in the picture. The middle finger's dorsal digital extension is not aided by the palmar interossei because they do not attach to the middle finger.

 

The palmar interossei muscles are also located between the metacarpal bones but are found on the palmar side of the hand. Their primary function is to adduct the fingers. Unlike the dorsal interossei, the palmar interossei insert only into the bases of the proximal phalanges and do not extend to the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd palmar interosseous does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Extensor hoods, also known as "dorsal digital expansions," are formed when the tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus muscles cross over the dorsal aspect of the digits and extend over the proximal phalanges. These hoods are connected by the tendons of the extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.

 

 

 

The dorsal digital expansion, also known as the extensor hood or extensor expansion, is a complex aponeurotic structure found on the dorsal aspect of each finger. It serves as the insertion point for certain tendons and allows the extensor tendons to provide extension at all three finger joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd Dorsal interossei: The dorsal interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones and are primarily responsible for the abduction of the fingers. There are four dorsal interossei in the hand. The tendons of the dorsal interossei insert into the bases of the proximal phalanges and into the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd dorsal interosseous does contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option B. Lumbricals: The lumbricals are four small muscles in the hand that arise from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons. Their primary function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. The tendons of the lumbricals insert into the dorsal digital expansion on the radial sides of the fingers. Hence, lumbricals do contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: The extensor digitorum muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. It extends down the forearm and sends tendons to the fingers. These tendons attach to the dorsal digital expansion and primarily facilitate the extension of the fingers. Thus, the extensor digitorum directly contributes to the formation of the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal digital expansion plays a key role in extending the finger joints and is formed by the integration of tendons from several muscles, excluding the 2nd Palmar interossei, which primarily functions in adduction and does not extend to the dorsal side of the fingers.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the overhead abduction of the arm? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pectoralis major

 

  • Pectoralis major is mainly involved in flexion, adduction and medial rotation of the arm (at the shoulder joint) and is not involved in the abduction of the arm.
  • Glenohumeral abduction is about 120° or more. The glenohumeral arthrodesis restricts the abduction at about 45°. Further abduction occurs at the sterno- and acromioclavicular articulations, and contralateral vertebral flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serratus Anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is involved in the overhead abduction of the arm. This muscle helps in the upward rotation of the scapula, allowing the arm to be raised overhead.

 

Option B. Deltoid: The deltoid muscle is a key muscle for overhead abduction of the arm. It has three distinct portions (anterior, middle, and posterior) that cover the shoulder joint. The middle portion of the deltoid is particularly responsible for abduction of the arm, lifting it away from the body.

 

Option C. Trapezius: The trapezius muscle also plays a role in the overhead abduction of the arm. The upper fibers of the trapezius assist in elevating the shoulder girdle, contributing to arm abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRINCIPLE MUSCLES ACTING ON SHOULDERS

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

 

IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2:

 

Role: IL-2 is crucial for T-cell proliferation, survival, and activation. It is not directly involved in the induction of IgE production by B-cells.

 

Option C. IL-1:

 

Role: IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, acting as a pro-inflammatory cytokine. It does not directly induce IgE production.

 

Option D. IL-6:

 

Role: IL-6 is important for inflammation, immune responses, and hematopoiesis. It has roles in the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it does not specifically induce IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is the key cytokine that stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE-secreting plasma cells, playing a crucial role in the allergic response and defense against parasites.

questions.text: A biochemistry student is studying enzyme kinetics and performs an experiment measuring the reaction velocity of an enzyme at different substrate concentrations. The resulting data is plotted as shown in the graph below, depicting a hyperbolic curve. Based on the shape of this graph, which type of enzyme kinetics is being demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Michaelis-Menten Kinetics

 

The graph shown depicts a hyperbolic curve, which is characteristic of Michaelis-Menten kinetics, a model that describes the rate of enzymatic reactions. In this model, the reaction velocity (v) increases with substrate concentration ([S]) and eventually reaches a maximum rate (Vmax) when the enzyme is saturated with substrate.

 

Michaelis-Menten Kinetics:

 

  1. Hyperbolic Curve: The shape of the curve is hyperbolic, showing a rapid initial increase in reaction velocity as substrate concentration increases, which gradually levels off as it approaches Vmax.
  2. Vmax (Maximum Velocity): Vmax represents the maximum rate of the reaction when the enzyme is fully saturated with the substrate, indicating that all active sites are occupied.
  3. Km (Michaelis Constant): Km is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax. It provides an indication of the enzyme's affinity for the substrate; a lower Km indicates higher affinity.
  4. Michaelis-Menten Equation: The rate of reaction follows the equation v=Vmax⋅[S]Km+[S]v = \frac{V_{max} \cdot [S]}{K_m + [S]}v=Km​+[S]Vmax​⋅[S]​, which describes how the reaction rate depends on substrate concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition Kinetics: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site, altering the apparent Km but not the Vmax, which is not depicted by a hyperbolic curve.

 

Option C. Non-Competitive Inhibition Kinetics: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor affects the reaction regardless of substrate concentration, leading to a decreased Vmax without changing Km.

 

Option D. Allosteric Enzyme Kinetics: Allosteric enzymes exhibit a sigmoidal (S-shaped) curve rather than a hyperbolic one, as they are regulated by binding at sites other than the active site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Michaelis-Menten kinetics describes the relationship between reaction velocity and substrate concentration in enzymes that follow simple, non-regulated pathways. The hyperbolic curve demonstrates the enzyme's increasing activity up to a maximum rate, illustrating key concepts like Vmax and Km that are foundational to understanding enzyme behavior in biochemical reactions.

choices.text: Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound, with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as type 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

 

GUSTILO AND ANDERSON CLASSIFICATION FOR OPEN FRACTURE

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm. This is the description of Type I of open fracture where the wound is clean and of <1cm length.  

 

Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury. This is the description of Type II of open fracture where the wound length is >1cm with mild soft tissue damage or skin flap or avulsion.

 

Option C. Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required. This is the description of Type IIIA of the open fracture where there is an adequate periosteal coverage present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIIB of the open fracture is the open wound with significant periosteal stripping.
  • It requires secondary bone coverage and procedures like skin grafting or flap.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

 

The amount of radiation exposure follows Inverse Square law which states that the radiation Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Small blood vessels are radiosensitive.

 

Option C: Cancer cells are rapidly proliferating cells are most radiosensitive.

 

Option D: Bone marrow, gonads, bowel mucosa possess high radiosensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the muscle responsible for the opening of the mouth? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. b

 

In the above image the structure marked ‘b’ represents the lateral pterygoid muscle which is responsible for opening the mouth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. a-Temporalis: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and retraction of mandible.

 

Option C. c – Medial pterygoid: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and ‘side-to-side’ movements of the mandible.

 

Option D. d –Buccinator: This muscle is responsible for compresses cheek against molar teeth
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: Identify the following lines: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blaschko lines

 

Blaschko lines, also known as Blaschko's lines, are an intricate and unique pattern of skin markings that follow a specific distribution on the human body. They are not visible under normal circumstances and only become apparent when certain skin conditions or genetic disorders manifest. They are thought to represent the migration and proliferation of embryonic cells during early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinderer’s lines - Two intersecting lines, one from the ala to the tragus and one from the lateral canthus.

 

 

Option B. Marionette lines are wrinkles at the corners of mouth

 

 

Option C. Relaxed skin tension lines refer to furrows that are created when the skin is pinched and relaxed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blaschko lines offer a fascinating insight into human embryonic development and their pattern can help diagnose several dermatological conditions. Each of these lines has specific implications in medical practice, particularly in dermatology, plastic surgery, and cosmetic procedures, illustrating the intersection of clinical knowledge with aesthetic considerations.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Broca's area

 

Broca's area (areas 44, 45) in this patient is damaged. This is located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, usually in the dominant hemisphere (the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals).

 

Function: Broca’s area is critical for speech production and grammar processing. Damage to Broca's area results in expressive or non-fluent aphasia. Patients typically understand spoken language and know what they want to say but struggle to form words or construct sentences. Their speech might be slow, with a struggle to find the right words, and they might omit small connecting words like "is" or "the."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's Area:

 

  • Location: This area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in about 95% of right-handed individuals and 70% of left-handed individuals.
  • Function: Wernicke's area is involved in language comprehension. Damage to this area results in receptive aphasia. Patients can produce speech, but it often lacks meaning, and they have difficulty understanding spoken or written language. Their speech might be fluent, but it's usually nonsensical or includes made-up words.

 

Option C. Heschl's Gyrus:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary auditory cortex within the Sylvian fissure in the temporal lobe.
  • Function: Heschl's gyrus is responsible for primary auditory processing, meaning it processes incoming auditory information. Damage to this area might impair the ability to perceive sounds.

 

Option D. Striate Area:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
  • Function: The striate area (or V1) is the primary processing center for visual information. Damage to this area can lead to blindness or partial visual field deficits depending on the extent and location of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anosmia

 

Kallmann syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the failure to start or fully complete puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It results from an isolated deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), and consequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Anosmia is the hallmark feature of Kallmann syndrome and helps differentiate it from other causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndactyly in males: This refers to the fusion of fingers or toes and is not characteristic of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Precocious puberty in females: This is an early onset of puberty, which is not associated with Kallmann syndrome, as this condition causes delayed or absent puberty.

 

Option D. White forelock: This is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, not Kallmann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anosmia is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to isolated GnRH deficiency.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of low-grade fever, muscle pain, and generalized weakness that has persisted for a few weeks. He mentions that he enjoys outdoor activities and recently traveled to a rural area where he engaged in gardening and consumed a variety of local foods, including meat dishes. Laboratory results show mild anemia and elevated inflammatory markers. Imaging is unremarkable. A diagram of a parasite’s lifecycle is provided. Based on the clinical scenario and the lifecycle shown, identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Toxoplasma gondii

 

The lifecycle depicted in the image is that of Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite responsible for toxoplasmosis. The lifecycle involves both definitive hosts (cats) and intermediate hosts (including humans, birds, and rodents).

 

Lifecycle Details:

 

  1. Definitive Hosts: The definitive hosts are members of the Felidae family, such as domestic cats, where the parasite undergoes its enteric cycle. Cats shed unsporulated oocysts in their feces, which become infective after 1-5 days in the environment.
  2. Intermediate Hosts: Birds, rodents, and other mammals, including humans, serve as intermediate hosts. They ingest oocysts from contaminated soil, water, or food, leading to the transformation of oocysts into tachyzoites that localize in muscle and neural tissues, forming tissue cysts.
  3. Transmission to Humans: Humans can acquire the infection through several routes:
  • Consuming undercooked or contaminated meat containing tissue cysts.
  • Ingesting oocysts from contaminated food, water, or environmental sources.
  • Transplacental transmission, blood transfusion, or organ transplantation.
  1. Clinical Impact: In humans, T. gondii can cause a range of symptoms, from mild flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The parasite forms tissue cysts in organs such as the brain, muscles, and eyes, where they can persist lifelong.

 

Diagnosis:

 

Diagnosis is typically achieved by serological testing for antibodies against T. gondii. In some cases, tissue cysts can be observed in stained biopsy specimens, and molecular methods like PCR can detect T. gondii DNA in amniotic fluid for congenital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium falciparum: The parasite responsible for malaria, transmitted by mosquito bites, and does not involve cats or environmental oocysts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: The causative agent of Chagas disease, transmitted by triatomine bugs, unrelated to the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Option D. Leishmania donovani: Causes leishmaniasis and is transmitted by sandflies. It does not involve environmental oocysts or cats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that cycles between definitive hosts (cats) and intermediate hosts (humans, birds, rodents). Understanding its lifecycle is essential in recognizing infection risks, especially through environmental exposure or consumption of contaminated food, and implementing appropriate preventive measures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenoma is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a condition in which the parathyroid glands produce excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to a stimulus other than low blood calcium levels. This can occur in response to various conditions that cause chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or exposure to certain medications such as lithium.

 

Parathyroid adenoma, on the other hand, is a cause of primary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by excess PTH secretion due to an abnormality within the parathyroid gland itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium intake: Lithium can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism by impairing calcium sensing.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is a well-known cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its role in calcium absorption.

 

Option D. Chronic kidney disease: CKD is a major cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its effects on phosphate and vitamin D metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism, whereas secondary hyperparathyroidism is due to external stimuli such as chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or lithium intake.

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

In obesity, there is typically an increase in insulin production due to insulin resistance. This resistance at the cellular level leads to impaired glucose uptake by cells, prompting the pancreas to secrete more insulin in an attempt to maintain normal blood glucose levels—a state referred to as compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Over time, this can strain the pancreas and exacerbate metabolic issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroxine levels are generally not increased in obesity; thyroid function can sometimes be altered, but not in the manner of increased production directly due to obesity.

 

Option C. Growth hormone: Growth hormone levels are often decreased in obesity. Growth hormone has lipolytic effects, helping to break down fats, and its lower levels in obesity are associated with an adverse metabolic profile.

 

Option D. Adiponectin: This is a hormone produced by adipose tissue that enhances insulin sensitivity and has anti-inflammatory effects. Levels of adiponectin are typically lower in individuals with obesity, which contributes to increased insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obesity, insulin resistance occurring due defect at receptors which causes compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence, their levels are reduced in obesity.

 

Reference - Harrison/Obesity

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complementation

 

The image shows a blue-white assay which uses the phenomenon of complementation (complementation of the galactosidase gene).

 

Blue-white assay: The target DNA is inserted into a vector. Vector is introduced into host cells for transformation and it grows in the presence of X-gal (X-gal detects active galactosidase). White colonies arise when cells are transformed with recombinant DNA-containing vectors; blue colonies form when cells are transformed with non-recombinant plasmids (i.e., just the vector).

 

Interpretation of Colonies:

 

  • White Colonies: These arise when the lacZ gene is disrupted by the insertion of foreign DNA, preventing the production of active beta-galactosidase. This indicates successful insertion of the foreign DNA.
  • Green Colonies: (Typically represented as blue colonies in traditional descriptions) These form when the lacZ gene remains intact, producing active beta-galactosidase that cleaves X-Gal, resulting in a blue color. This indicates the vector did not take up the foreign DNA or the insert is outside the lacZ gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translation: This process involves the synthesis of proteins from mRNA and is not related to the phenomenon shown in the image.

 

Option B. Transformation: While transformation is a part of the process where bacterial cells take up the plasmid DNA, the specific phenomenon depicted is complementation in the blue-white screening assay.

 

Option D. Conjugation: This is a method of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria involving direct cell-to-cell contact and is unrelated to the process shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blue-white screening assay uses the complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene to distinguish between bacterial colonies with recombinant and non-recombinant plasmids based on the color change in the presence of X-Gal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy. She came to the hospital after one week with acute pain in the abdomen with features suggestive of perforation. An X-ray showed the following picture. Identify the type of offense for which the surgeon can be held responsible? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Res ipsa loquitur

 

  • The X-ray indicates surgical scissors accidentally left behind during surgery.
  • The surgeon can be held guilty for Res ipsa loquitur.
  • "Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself."
  • The negligent act by the doctor is obvious from the Xray and the patient need not prove the negligence.
  • Conditions to be fulfilled to prove negligence:
  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • There was no contributory negligence from the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: Refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation. It is not applicable here as the negligence was directly related to the surgery.

 

Option C. Res judicata: Refers to a matter that has been adjudicated by a competent court and therefore cannot be pursued further by the same parties. It is not relevant to the context of proving negligence.

 

Option D. Vicarious liability: Refers to the liability of one party for the actions of another, typically an employer for an employee. This does not directly apply to the surgeon's individual negligence in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of surgical instruments left inside a patient post-operation is a clear case of negligence, aptly described by the legal principle of "Res ipsa loquitur," meaning the fact speaks for itself.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is undergoing chronic medication therapy for a long-term condition. The healthcare team wants to maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug. What formula should be used to calculate the maintenance dose rate of the drug for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clearance x Plasma concentration

 

The formula for the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is generally expressed as:

 

Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL) × Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp) 

 

This formula aims to achieve a steady-state concentration of the drug in the bloodstream. By multiplying the clearance rate by the desired plasma concentration, you get the rate at which the drug should be administered to maintain that desired concentration.

 

Note –

 

The loading dose is designed to quickly achieve the desired therapeutic level, whereas the maintenance dose sustains that level over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula for calculating the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is:

 

Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL)×Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp)

 

This formula is used to achieve and maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug

questions.text:
During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

 

  1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge
  2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia
  3. Watch for Headache and nasal discharge
  4. Monitor glucose levels
  5. Watch for Sinusitis-like symptoms
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4 and 5

 

Discharging a COVID-19 patient involves providing instructions for monitoring ongoing or potential symptoms and managing side effects of treatments such as steroids and remdesivir.

 

3. Watch for headache and nasal discharge: These symptoms can be part of the post-COVID syndrome or could indicate secondary infections like sinusitis, especially after treatment that might suppress the immune system.

 

4. Monitor glucose levels: Steroids, often used in the treatment of severe COVID-19, can elevate blood glucose levels. It’s crucial for patients, especially those with pre-existing diabetes or those who experienced high glucose levels during treatment, to monitor their levels after discharge.

 

5. Watch for sinusitis-like symptoms: As with headache and nasal discharge, symptoms like those of sinusitis might suggest secondary infections, which are important to monitor given the use of immunomodulating treatments like steroids.

 

Other Options:
 

1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge: Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge is not required as per updated guidelines. Repeat RT-PCR at 7 days of discharge was initially suggested, but later on removed from the guideline. 
 

2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia: Watch for the persistence of Anosmia is a common symptom (Anosmia can persist for weeks together) but, not matching with the options (actual answer should be 2,3,4, and 5).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients recovering from COVID-19 should monitor for symptoms of headache and nasal discharge, glucose levels due to steroid use, and sinusitis-like symptoms which could indicate secondary infections like mucormycosis.

questions.text: Bone mineral density screening is recommended after the age of:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 65 years

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae
