  • Bone mineral density screening by DEXA scan is recommended at the age more than 65 years.

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B

 

The coracoid process is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa and is marked on the scapula as B. The coracoid process's tip is located approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). As a result, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forwards and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include

 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament
  • Pectoralis minor
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromian process continues from the spine of the scapula. The acromion is subcutaneous over its dorsal surface, The attachments at the acromion are the coracoacromial ligament, the articular capsule of the acromioclavicular joint, and horizontal fibers of the trapezius.

 

Option C. The glenoid fossa is present at the lateral angle of the scapula. It is articular with the humerus to form the shoulder joint.

 

Option D. The inferior angle lies over the seventh rib. Dorsally, it is related to latissimus dorsi. The angle is visible when the arm is raised over the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process is a palpable landmark in the infraclavicular fossa, important for clinical examination and as a reference point for various shoulder procedures. Its recognition is crucial in the assessment of shoulder pathologies and for orientation during surgical approaches to the shoulder.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is scheduled for a tonsillectomy due to recurrent tonsillitis. The anesthesiologist is considering an inhalational anesthetic that can be used for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. The goal is to provide a smooth, rapid induction with minimal airway irritation, making it suitable for pediatric patients and facilitating safe endotracheal intubation. Which of the following anesthetic agents is best suited for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is a widely used inhalational anesthetic, especially in pediatric patients, due to its favorable profile for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a non-pungent, sweet smell, making it well-tolerated during inhalation induction, particularly in children who may be anxious about intravenous lines.

 

Induction and Maintenance: Sevoflurane is ideal for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its non-irritating nature facilitates smooth induction, which is crucial in pediatric patients who may be sensitive to more pungent anesthetics.

 

Safe for Endotracheal Intubation: Sevoflurane helps maintain airway stability during induction, reducing the risk of laryngospasm or coughing, which is especially important when performing endotracheal intubation in children.

 

Rapid Onset and Recovery: Sevoflurane’s low blood-gas solubility allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in outpatient settings and for procedures requiring a quick recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is more suitable for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor, which can irritate the airway and cause discomfort, particularly in pediatric patients.

 

Option B. Nitrous oxide: Nitrous oxide is often used as an adjunct but does not provide sufficient anesthetic depth on its own for induction or maintenance and lacks bronchodilatory properties.

 

Option D. Propofol: Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic that is excellent for induction and maintenance but is not inhaled and does not provide the bronchodilatory effects that sevoflurane offers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational anesthetic for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its rapid onset, non-irritating properties, and ability to facilitate smooth and safe endotracheal intubation. This makes it a valuable agent in managing anesthesia in young patients undergoing surgical procedures.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mineralocorticoids

 

After a trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, the pituitary gland's ability to produce several hormones including ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH can be impaired. The lack of ACTH typically necessitates glucocorticoid replacement, but not mineralocorticoid supplementation. This is because the regulation of mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone) is mainly via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which operates independently of the pituitary gland. Aldosterone secretion is primarily controlled by plasma potassium levels and the RAAS, not ACTH, although ACTH can have a stimulatory effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: Low dose steroid supplementation is required as they are ACTH dependent.

 

Option C. Thyroid hormones: Necessary due to diminished TSH, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion. LT4 supplementation targeting T4 levels is required.

 

Option D. Estradiol: While gonadotropin supplementation post-pituitary surgery can be complex, replacement might be necessary due to the absence of FSH and LH, affecting estrogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Post-hypophysectomy, patients often require supplementation of several hormones, including glucocorticoids and thyroid hormones, due to impaired pituitary function. However, mineralocorticoid supplementation is typically not needed as aldosterone secretion is primarily regulated by the RAAS system, independent of pituitary control.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Chapter 379/

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Pyruvate carboxylase

B. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxy kinase

C. Hexokinase

D. Pyruvate kinase

E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A and E only

 

Gluconeogenesis bypasses the three irreversible steps of glycolysis using four specific enzymes. From the given options, only two are actual gluconeogenic enzymes. Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria, requiring ATP and biotin as cofactor. This is the first step in bypassing the pyruvate kinase reaction. Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which allows glucose release from liver and kidney cells. This enzyme is absent in muscle, explaining why muscle cannot contribute glucose to the bloodstream despite having glycogen stores.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (A, B and E only): "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" is not a real enzyme - this appears to be a nomenclature error. The actual gluconeogenic enzyme is phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), which converts oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

 

Option B (B and C only): Neither enzyme participates in gluconeogenesis. "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" doesn't exist, and hexokinase catalyzes the forward glycolytic reaction (glucose → glucose-6-phosphate), consuming ATP rather than producing glucose.

 

Option D (A, B and C only): This includes both the non-existent "phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" and hexokinase, which is a glycolytic enzyme that would oppose gluconeogenesis by converting free glucose back to glucose-6-phosphate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among the listed enzymes, only pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are genuine gluconeogenic enzymes that help bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis to synthesize glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors.

choices.text: 90% is associated with ANCA positivity
30% is associated with Hepatitis B

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 30% association with Hepatitis B

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis predominantly affecting medium-sized arteries, often associated with Hepatitis B in about 30% of cases. The association with Hepatitis B is significant because the virus can trigger immune complex deposition, contributing to vascular inflammation and damage characteristic of PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing inflammation of large vessels: This is incorrect because PAN specifically affects medium-sized, not large vessels. Large vessel vasculitis includes conditions like Giant Cell Arteritis and Takayasu Arteritis.

 

Option B. Patient has hypogammaglobulinemia: This is incorrect; PAN is often associated with hypergammaglobulinemia due to chronic immune activation, not hypogammaglobulinemia.

 

Option C. 90% is associated with ANCA positivity: This statement is also incorrect. Polyarteritis nodosa is typically ANCA-negative; the presence of ANCA is more characteristic of other forms of vasculitis such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper IgM syndrome: This immunodeficiency disorder is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to defects in class-switch recombination. Patients are more prone to infections but not specifically with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Patients with Job syndrome have elevated levels of IgE and suffer from recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, pneumonia, and other infections. However, their susceptibility is not specifically related to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to impaired phagocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. While patients are prone to infections, their susceptibility is not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estradiol

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can promote the growth of endometriotic lesions. Estradiol is a form of estrogen, which can stimulate the endometrial tissue and potentially exacerbate the symptoms and progression of endometriosis. The goal in managing endometriosis is to reduce estrogen levels or block estrogen’s effects to help resolve the lesions and alleviate symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is used in the treatment of endometriosis. Medroxyprogesterone acetate is a type of progesterone that helps create a state of endometrial atrophy, which can reduce the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Option B. Cabergoline: This drug is typically used to treat hyperprolactinemia but is not a standard treatment for endometriosis. While not commonly used in endometriosis management, its use is not contraindicated as estradiol is.

 

Option D. Letrozole: This is an aromatase inhibitor that lowers estrogen levels and is used in the treatment of endometriosis. By reducing estrogen levels, letrozole helps decrease the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can exacerbate the condition by promoting the growth of endometriotic lesions

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about intestinal transplantation: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts

 

This statement is incorrect. While multi-visceral transplantation, which includes the intestine along with other abdominal organs like the liver and pancreas, can occur, it is not the most common type of intestinal transplantation. Isolated intestinal transplantation, where only the intestine is transplanted, is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: This statement is correct. Intestinal transplantation is not as widely performed as other organ transplants like kidney or liver transplantation because the intestine is known to trigger vigorous rejection reactions.

 

Option C. The most dangerous complication is sepsis: This statement is correct. Sepsis is indeed a significant and life-threatening complication associated with intestinal transplantation. The immunosuppressive medications used to prevent rejection can increase the risk of infections, including sepsis.

 

Option D. The most common indication is ischemia. (Correct): Ischemia is one of the common indications for intestinal transplantation. It is often used when patients have suffered from ischemic bowel disease and other treatments have been ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-visceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

 

All the other statements are correct.

 

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option when the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

 

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic as it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56-75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.

questions.text: Decreased transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

  

Transferrin saturation is a measure of the percentage of transferrin (iron-transporting protein) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, there is a lack of sufficient iron to saturate transferrin, leading to a decreased transferrin saturation. This occurs because the body has insufficient iron for proper incorporation into hemoglobin and other iron-containing proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromatosis: In hemochromatosis, there is an excessive absorption and accumulation of iron in the body. This condition leads to increased transferrin saturation, as the body has an excess of iron.

 

Option C. Macrocytic anemia: Macrocytic anemia refers to anemia with larger-than-normal red blood cells. It is commonly associated with deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid. Transferrin saturation is not typically a characteristic feature of macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Hemosiderosis: Hemosiderosis refers to the deposition of excess iron in tissues. Like hemochromatosis, it is associated with increased transferrin saturation due to iron overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of transferrin saturation and how it relates to various conditions related to iron metabolism. Decreased transferrin saturation is typically seen in conditions of iron deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, where there is insufficient iron to fully saturate transferrin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a palpable lump in her neck that she noticed a few weeks ago. She has no significant pain but feels some discomfort when swallowing. On physical examination, the lump is located in the anterior neck region, just below the Adam’s apple. The physician orders an imaging study to evaluate the thyroid gland and surrounding neck structures for further assessment. Based on the imaging modality shown in the image provided, identify the technique used.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ultrasound (USG) of the neck

 

The given image is suggestive of a sonographic examination (USG) of the neck, commonly used to evaluate the thyroid gland and surrounding structures. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality because it provides high-resolution images of soft tissues, including the thyroid gland, muscles, blood vessels, and other neck structures without exposing the patient to ionizing radiation.

 

Key Features of USG in Neck Imaging:

 

  1. Thyroid Gland: The thyroid appears as a homogeneously hyperechoic structure with a uniform echotexture on ultrasound, making it easy to evaluate for nodules, cysts, and other abnormalities.
  2. Adjacent Structures:
    • Muscles: Sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and strap muscles (STM) can be visualized anteriorly and laterally.
    • Blood Vessels: The common carotid artery (CCA) and internal jugular vein (JV) are visible laterally to the thyroid lobes.
    • Trachea: The trachea is seen centrally, characterized by its circular appearance with hyperechoic rings.
  3. Clinical Application:
    • USG is particularly useful in evaluating thyroid nodules, guiding fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsies, and assessing vascular structures. It is the investigation of choice (IOC) for thyroid evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Scan of the neck: CT scans provide excellent detail of bony structures and soft tissues but involve radiation and are not as sensitive as USG for thyroid evaluation.

 

Option B. MRI of the neck: MRI is used for soft tissue contrast in complex cases but is not the first-line imaging for thyroid or neck lump assessment due to cost and time factors.

 

Option D. X-ray of the neck: X-rays have limited use in evaluating soft tissues and are primarily used for visualizing bony structures and the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound is the ideal imaging modality for assessing the thyroid gland and neck structures due to its ability to provide detailed, real-time images of soft tissues without radiation exposure. It is crucial for diagnosing and managing thyroid-related conditions and evaluating palpable neck lumps.

questions.text: NADPH is used in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fatty acid synthesis

 

NADPH is essential for fatty acid synthesis. During this process, NADPH provides reducing equivalents necessary for the conversion of acetyl-CoA into long-chain fatty acids. This reduction step is crucial for building the carbon chains that make up fatty acids, and NADPH acts as a reducing agent in this pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketone Synthesis: NADPH is not directly involved in ketone synthesis. Ketones are typically synthesized from fatty acids during a state of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: NADPH plays a role in gluconeogenesis, which is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. NADPH is required for certain enzymatic reactions in this pathway, such as the reduction of oxaloacetate to malate.

 

Option D. Glycolysis: NADPH is not directly involved in glycolysis. Glycolysis primarily uses NAD+ (Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide) rather than NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH generating reactions

 

  1. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (Glucose-6-phosphate → 6-phospho-glucono lactone)
  2. 6-phospho gluconate dehydrogenase in the shunt pathway (6-phospho gluconate → 3-keto-6-phospho gluconate)
  3. Cytoplasmic isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Malic enzyme (malate to pyruvate).

 

NADPH utilizing reactions

 

  1. Ketoacyl-ACP dehydrogenase (Beta-ketoacyl-ACP → beta hydroxy acyl ACP) (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 4)
  2. Alpha, beta unsaturated acyl ACP → Acyl ACP (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 6)
  3. HMG CoA reductase (HMG CoA → mevalonate (Cholesterol synthesis)
  4. Met-hemoglobin → Hemoglobin
  5. Folate reductase (Folate → dihydrofolate → tetrahydrofolate)
  6. Phenyl alanine hydroxylase (Phenylalanine → tyrosine)

questions.text: Match the following transporters with the molecule they carry. (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1c, 2d, 3a, 4b

 

Hemopexin transports free heme. Haptoglobin binds to and transports hemoglobin. Pre-albumin, also known as transthyretin, transports thyroxin and retinol binding protein. Albumin transports various hydrophobic substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and many drugs. The correct match is:

 

  1. Hemopexin - c. Heme
    Hemopexin specifically binds and transports free heme to prevent its oxidative damage.
  2. Haptoglobin - d. Hemoglobin
    Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, preventing loss of iron and kidney damage.
  3. Pre-albumin - a. Thyroxin
    Pre-albumin (transthyretin) transports thyroxin (T4) and retinol-binding protein.
  4. Albumin - b. Free fatty acid
    Albumin transports a wide range of substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and various drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match can be given as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 630-631

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles.

 

 

  • Complicated or secondary cataracts develop due to inflammatory or degenerative conditions of the lens or other parts of the eye.
  • Causes of these cataracts include iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors which disturb the nutrition of the lens.
  • These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster.
  • Vision impairment occurs even in the early stages due to location of the cataract at the nodal point.
  • Inflammation of the posterior segment causes posterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: This is a feature seen in complicated cataracts where the lens exhibits a colorful sheen, often described as having a "christmas tree" or polychromatic appearance, particularly noticeable under slit-lamp examination.

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Uveitis, an inflammatory disease affecting the uveal tract of the eye, can lead to the development of complicated cataracts. Chronic inflammation can disrupt the lens, leading to cataract formation.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: This refers to the appearance of small opacities within the lens, resembling breadcrumbs, commonly seen in complicated cataracts due to intraocular inflammation or other degenerative changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Krukenberg spindle is a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea, commonly seen in pigmentary glaucoma. It results from the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris that adhere to the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

 

Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

 

  • Indications for myomectomy in a woman with infertility and fibroid uterus include:
    • Submucous fibroids of any size/location as they interfere with fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
    • Intramural fibroids that:
      • Distort the endometrial cavity.
      • Are larger than 5 cm in size.
  • In this case, the patient has significant intramural fibroids (7x5 cm and 5x3 cm), making laparoscopic myomectomy the appropriate management to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: This procedure is not indicated for women who wish to conceive as it can compromise uterine function and future fertility.

 

Option C. Artificial reproductive techniques: While ART could be considered in cases of bilateral tubal block, myomectomy should be done prior to potentially relieve the tubal block, improve ART outcomes, and enhance pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. GnRH analogues: GnRH analogues are not suitable for this patient as she is eager to conceive. These are typically used for temporary symptom relief or to shrink fibroids preoperatively, but not as a primary treatment for infertility in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Actinomycetes israelli

 

This clinical history is suggestive of cervicofacial actinomycosis which is caused by Actinomyces israeli.

 

Actinomyces are non-sporeforming, filamentous, and facultative anaerobes. They are normal constituents of the oral flora within gingival crevices and tonsillar crypts and are particularly prevalent in periodontal pockets, dental plaques, and on carious teeth.

 

Actinomyces bacteria cannot penetrate healthy tissue, and mucosal breakdown is a prerequisite for infection. Poor dental hygiene, caries, oral trauma, dental extraction, and an immunocompromised status are considered to be important antecedents.

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis or lumpy jaw is the most frequent clinical form of actinomycosis, and “lumpy jaw syndrome”, which is associated with odontogenic infection, is the most common clinical manifestation.

 

It presents as a painless or occasionally painful soft-tissue swelling involving the submandibular or perimandibular region; over time, multiple sinuses drain pus containing sulfur granules; tendency to remit and recur. There is reddish or bluish discoloration of the skin overlying the lesion, chewing difficulties (i.e., with involvement of mastication muscles) are also seen.

 

Other types -

 

  • Thoracic actinomycosis- 
    • History of aspiration (Risk factors include seizure disorder, alcoholism, and poor dental hygiene.)
    • Dry or productive cough, occasionally blood-streaked sputum, shortness of breath, chest pain pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- 
    • History of abdominal surgery, perforated viscus, mesenteric vascular insufficiency, or ingestion of foreign bodies (e.g., fish or chicken bones)
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- 
    • History of IUCD
    • Lower abdominal discomfort, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge

 

A Gram-stained smear of the specimen may demonstrate the presence of beaded, branched, gram-positive filamentous rods, with a sun ray appearance suggesting the diagnosis of actinomycosis.

 

 

Culture - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies.

 

Treatment - Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin’s such as amoxicillin are now popular. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: This is a chronic fungal infection characterized by verrucous skin lesions, typically affecting the lower extremities. It does not present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: This is a severe fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. It usually affects immunocompromised individuals and presents with rhino-orbital-cerebral or pulmonary infections, not typically associated with submandibular masses and sulfur granules.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, primarily affecting the lungs and sometimes disseminating in immunocompromised individuals. It does not typically present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis, commonly caused by Actinomyces israelii, presents with submandibular masses, often after dental procedures, with foul-smelling discharge containing yellow sulfur granules. Gram staining reveals gram-positive filamentous rods, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple screening test includes Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein (AFP), and Inhibin A. Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple test.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A school going child had applied henna and comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis artefacta

 

The given image points towards a likely diagnosis of dermatitis Artefacta.

 

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a psychodermatological disorder where lesions are self-inflicted, often due to psychological stress or disorders. The pattern of the lesions, which are well-circumscribed and may follow an accessible pattern that the child could reach, is suggestive of dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition in which the patient deliberately produces skin lesions without any rational motive. This is a psychological ailment where the patient is fully aware of their actions.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Indicated by the symmetrical placement of lesions in accessible areas on the face, neck, chest etc. Additionally, the lesions may exhibit varying stages of healing, similar to an abrasion.
  • These visible symptoms of dermatitis artefacta can be seen as a form of nonverbal communication, representing a "cry for attention and help" from a patient who is unable to express their needs through meaningful verbal communication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis due to henna:

 

  • Contact dermatitis from henna, often related to the chemical para-phenylenediamine (PPD), usually manifests as a diffuse, erythematous rash in areas where the henna was applied.
  • If the reaction were due to henna, one would expect to see an affected scalp where the henna was applied.
  • However, the presence of localized lesions on the cheek and the normal appearance of the scalp suggests that this is not a case of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) caused by henna.

 

Option C. Polymorphic light eruption (PLE):

 

  • This is an abnormal reaction to sunlight it is not expected to have a direct correlation with the application of henna.
  • Lesions will be small, itchy papules or Papulo-vesicles on an erythematous background. They will also be monomorphic (unlike as the name suggests).

 

Option D. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin and would not present with erythematous or inflamed lesions as shown in the image.
  • It represents a loss of pigment and is not physically raised or inflamed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing skin lesions, it's important to consider the psychological aspect of dermatology.
  • Dermatitis artefacta should be suspected in lesions that are localized, well-circumscribed, and do not have a distribution pattern consistent with the history or other physical causes.

 

Ref:

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology 9th edition 128.13

Kaplan & Saddocks concise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page 435, 436

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition 405

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.
